'Trinity' was the code name of the first detonation of a nuclear device. This
test was conducted by the United States Army on July 16, 1945, Ferenc Morton
Szasz, The Day The Sun Rose Twice: The Story of the Trinity Site Nuclear
Explosion July 16, 1945 (University of New Mexico Press, 1984). ISBN 978-0-8263-0768-
2 in the Jornada del Muerto
desert about southeast of Socorro, New Mexico, at the new White Sands Proving
Ground, which incorporated the Alamogordo Bombing and Gunnery Range. (The site
is now the White Sands Missile Range.) The date of the
test is usually considered to be the beginning of the Atomic Age.

Trinity was a test of an implosion-design plutonium device. The weapon's
informal nickname was "The Gadget". Kathryn Westcott:
[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4641861.stm bbc.co.uk The day the world lit
up], BBC, Friday, 15 July 2005. Using the same conceptual design, the Fat
Man device was detonated over Nagasaki, Japan, on August 9, 1945. The Trinity
detonation produced the explosive power of about .
